description.narrative: Focusing on improving food security, nutrition and protection for conflict-affected communities in Koch (Unity State), the SSJR 7 project will provide emergency livelihood inputs, strengthen VSLA groups, raise awareness on CP and GBV and provide PSS through Child-Friendly Spaces and Women and Girls Friendly spaces. Nutrition activities include outreach, mobilisation, preventive and curative services to children < 5 and pregnant and lactacting women.

title.narrative: Percentage of budget that went to national and local actors

comment.narrative: 10% (66834 Euro: HDC=43425 Euro, UNIDOR= 23409 Euro) of the budget went to the national partners for Q1 and the subsequent budget will be transferred to the national partners as per the partnership agreements.

title.narrative: Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific GBV prevention measures

comment.narrative: 1128 individuals reached with EMAP activities in the 5 Bomas ( Jahjah, Petpet, Jaak, Bang and Koat). The EMAP process started with the deification of the facilitators and EMAP training. 17 individuals were trained on EMAP and the objectives of the training were: to successfully implement the phases and use the tools of the EMAP intervention, understanding and using accountable practice throughout the intervention, responding effectively to challenges that may arise during the intervention and prioritizing the voices of women throughout the intervention.

title.narrative: Number of children that received support specified to their needs

comment.narrative: 1625 children were reached with recreational activities at the CFSs of Bang, Jaak, Kuachlual and Petpet. 32 children were also reached with case management. At the CFSs, UNIDOR disseminates CP messages which include information on the different forms of threats that endanger children. UNIDOR is currently implementing CP in five child Friendly Spaces (CFSs) namely Bang (Gany Payam), Koat (Kuachlual Payam) and Jaak Payam.

title.narrative: Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus

comment.narrative: 17 benefitted from case management training. The training is planned for 3 sessions to ensure social distancing and the subsequent trainings are planned for May 2021. The objectives of the training were: to support field-based delivery of quality survivor-centred, age-appropriate, GBV prevention, mitigation and response that meet global minimum services, as well as building capacity of frontline workers.

title.narrative: Number of survivors who receive an appropriate response to GBV

comment.narrative: 25 GBV survivors received an appropriate GBV response and case management. These GBV survivors included rape (4), physical assault (14), forced marriage (4) and psychological/emotional abuse (5).The GBV survivors were provided with case management, provided with counselling/PFA and later enrolled to PSS activities such as ed sheet sewing, hair dressing, knitting woollen threads, making local jewellery out of beads (e.g. necklaces), traditional songs and dances so that they recover from the trauma. CARE SS also provided the GBV Survivors with dignity kits that were received from UNFPA. There has be rise in GBV cases due to the recent incident that occurred in Jahjah as a result of conflict between the SSPF and the armed youth due to a cattle raid.

title.narrative: Number of people screened for under nutrition

comment.narrative: 4656 children of 6-59 months were screened for malnutrition during using MUAC tape as per the SSJR standards for conducting quarterly mass screening. Children who were severely or moderately malnourished were referred for admission to OTP and TSFP program. 8568 PLWs were also screened for malnutrition. In addition to MUAc screening, there was also checking for bilateral pitting oedema. After every measurement, the MUAC tape was sanitized as per the new COVID-19 guidelines. The activity is on track and the target will be reached on time. CARE SS is implementing the nutrition programme in line with the MOH National CMAM guideline with emphasis on community outreach, Outpatient Therapeutic Programme (OTP) and Targeted Supplementary Feeding Programme (TSFP), and referring the children who are severely malnourished (SAM) with medical complications to the stabilization centre (SC) under World Relief integrated in Koch County Hospital.

title.narrative: Number of children under 5 admitted for treatment of Severe or Moderate Acute Malnutrition

comment.narrative: 551 severely and moderately malnourished children were admitted to the nutrition programs of Jahjah, Bang, Jahjah and Petpet for treatment of acute malnutrition.

title.narrative: Number of persons who receive an appropriate response

comment.narrative: 556 individuals were reached with PSS activities such as bead and bedsheet making, fuel efficient stove distribution, hair dressing, games (skipping ropes, throwing plates and valley balls) and traditional songs and dances which provided trauma healing to the GBV survivors at the WGFs. The challenge faced during the reporting period was the inadequate PSS materials from the centres and the delay to timely procurement of the PSS materials as ordered. However, the WGFS benefitted from the Reconciliation, Stabilisation and Resilient Trust Fund (RSRTF) project though there was delay to timely delivery of project supplies, which are expected to be delivered by the end of April as the truck is on the way from Juba to Koch.

title.narrative: Number of pregnant or lactating women admitted for treatment of Severe or Moderate Acute Malnutrition

comment.narrative: 695 females under 18 were admitted to the TSFP program for treatment. These PLWs are also enrolled to MIYCN activities and bi-weekly mother-to-mother support groups and Maternal and Infant Young Care Nutrition (MIYCN) counselling sessions focusing on nutrition sensitive interventions and targeting pregnant and lactating women with children under 24 months. There are 13 groups of MTMSG (169 members) in the 3 centres; Bang 5 groups with 67 members, Jajah with 3 groups of 36 members and Petpet 5 groups with 66 members who conduct messaging on MIYCN counselling sessions on a bi-weekly basis. Each group consists of 10-12 members and headed by a lead mother. Topics of discussions include early initiation of breast feeding, exclusive breastfeeding, complementary feeding, prevention of diarrhoea, health seeking behaviour, care during the pregnancy and avoiding open defecation to prevent the transmission of waterborne diseases.

title.narrative: Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements

comment.narrative: 6983 individuals were reached with awareness raising messaging on the GBV/CP and risk communication and community engagement on COVID-19 preventive measures. The topics of discussion during these sessions included dispelling myths about violence against women, services available for GBV survivors, early and forced marriages' consequences, domestic violence and its consequences, the benefits of seeking timely help, the causes and contributing factors of violence against women and girls, understanding the consequence of violence on different people in the community, Identifying how norms are created and can change. Due to COVID-19 measures, the awareness raising was conducted in adherence to SOPs including provision of hand washing facilities and sanitizers. The challenge encountered was delay to delivered soap used during the awareness which slowed the activity's implementation.

title.narrative: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

comment.narrative: CARE SS with its national partners continue to strengthen accountability with the established AAP system comprising of the Project Management Committees, the new formed Community Accountability Committee, the AAP Committee. Participation of the beneficiaries in project design, planning, implementation and monitoring and evaluation has been supported.

title.narrative: Number of health facilities where nutrition programmes are implemented

comment.narrative: The nutrition activities such as the treatment and preventive community outreach at the three OTP/TSFP Nutrition centers are normally implemented to provide life saving service to the malnourished children and PLWs. CARE SS closely implements the nutrition programme in collaboration with the CHD, WFP and Unicef and these partners provide the nutrition supplies and essential drugs such as amoxicillin. The nutrition programme is being implemented in line with the MOH National COVID-19 CMAM guideline with focus to the three CMAM components namely; Community outreach, Outpatient Therapeutic Programme (OTP) and Targeted Supplementary Feeding Programme (TSFP), and referring the children who are severely malnourished (SAM) with medical complications to the stabilization center (SC) under World Relief integrated in Koch County Hospital. As part of coordination, CARE SS submits weekly and monthly reports to Unicef, WFP and the County Health Department and also participates in the coordination meetings and joint support supervision. CARE SS also integrates Risk Communication and Community Engagement on COVID-19 prevention messages. The CHD, WFP and UNICEf has led to effective implementation of the nutrition programme. The only challenge was in Jahjah when the nutrition center was looted by the SSPDF during the conflict with the armed youth in the community.

title.narrative: Percentage of budget spent on capacity building of national an local actors

comment.narrative: This particular activity is planned in the next quarter

title.narrative: Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

comment.narrative: This particular activity is planned in the next quarter

title.narrative: Number of adaptations in the design and/or implementation of the JR, as a result of the input from beneficiaries.

comment.narrative: Through the PMCs, 12 adaptations have been incorporated in the programme during the implementation, including: participation during the feasibility studies for the project supplies such as FSl inputs, PSS materials, selection and setting up of the 10 demo gardens, site selection for the IGA shelters and selection of the sites for the CFSs among others. CARE SS will continue to engage the PMCs and beneficiaries to participate during the project design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation to ensure quality of project activities.

title.narrative: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets

comment.narrative: Through the PMCs, HDC registered 10800 individuals for the FSL inputs pending distribution of the seeds and tools which are expected to be delivered in Koch before the end of April 2021. The beneficiaries include the PWD, elderly, female-headed households, IDPs, returnees and the host community across the 3 Payams of Jaak ( Jahjah, Gaap, Petpe Bomas), Kuachlual (Koat Boma) and Gany (Bang Boma) Payam. The process began with feasibility studies for seed preference availability. 67 individuals participated during the feasibility studies. The feasibility studies highlighted the need for HDC to procure seeds outside Koch, due to flooding effects. The VSLA members are scaling up the IGA activities as most of them are now engage in petty businesses such as fish retailing, tea making, restaurant, making local brew, selling charcoal to improve the household basic needs such food, clothing and health. HDC will continue to monitor the VSLA activities to improve its quality.
